sec.p:
African Invertebrates Vol. 43 Pages 1–3
Pietermaritzburg December, 2002

The true identity of the Ethiopian centipede
Scolopendra gardullana Attems
( Chilopoda : Scolopendromorpha : Scolopendridae )
by

sec.title: John G. E. Lewis
sec.p:
(
Somerset County Museum , Taunton Castle, Castle Green, Taunton, Somerset TA1 4AA, UK ; for correspondence: Manor Mill Farm, Halse, Taunton, Somerset , TA4 3AQ, UK ; Johngelewis@aol.com)

sec.title: ABSTRACT
sec.p:
The Ethiopian centipede
Scolopendra gardullana Attems
is shown to be a junior synonym of
Scolopendra afer (Meinert)
, a widespread African species.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p:
Scolopendra gardullana Attems, 1909
was described from Gardulla in southern Ethiopia . The description, which was repeated in
, appears to have been based on a single specimen.

Lewis (2001) gave details of two specimens of
Scolopendra afer (Meinert, 1886)
from Moshi , Tanzania , noting that although they compared well with Attems’ (1930) description (as
Trachycormocephalus afer
) they ran down to
Scolopendra gardullana
in Attems’ key, and suggested that the two species might be conspecific.
showed that
Trachycormocephalus
was a junior synonym of
Scolopendra
.

Dr Jason Dunlop kindly arranged a loan of what is regarded as the holotype of
S. gardullana
, in the collection of the Museum für Naturkunde, Humboldt-Universität, Berlin. It is here redescribed and its status reassessed.

sec.title: TAXONOMY
sec.p:
Material Examined: One specimen (regarded as holotype ) labelled:
Scolopendra gardullana
n.sp. Attems. ZMB Kat Nr 4711. Syntypus . Gardulla 11.1.1901 . O. Neumann.
Description (Attems’ (1909) data in parentheses where appropriate):
The specimen lacks most of it legs and the anterior part is bent ventrally. Length 40 mm approx. ( 50 mm ).
Ultimate leg prefemur with 2 ventrolateral, 2 ventral, 3 or 4 ventromedial, 3 dorsomedial spines and a two-spined prefemoral process.
Legs without femoral or tibial spines, 1–19 with one tarsal, 20 and 21 without (19 and 20 without tarsal spine). All legs with 2 claw spines.

Remarks :
description of
S. gardullana
gives no indication that he examined more than one specimen . The vial containing the species, however, has a label ‘
syntypus
’ and
list of myriapod types in the Zoology Museum Berlin give:
1 exemplar, Syntypus
. Dr Verena Stagl informs me that there are no specimens in the Natural History Museum in Vienna (which houses Attems’ collection). She states that it was not his practice to send syntypes to other museums, and presumes that he had to return the O. Neumann material to Berlin. It seems very probable then, that Attems had before him only a single specimen, and that it was therefore the holotype , and it is here regarded as such.

As noted above Attems’ statements that
S. gardullana
has two spines on the dorsal ridge of the coxopleuron and that leg 19 has no tarsal spine are incorrect. It has no dorsal spines on the coxopleuron and has a tarsal spine on leg 19.

The specimen of
S. gardullana
is clearly
S. afer
, which is a well defined species. It lacks cephalic sutures, but this falls within the variation indicated for
T. afer
by
, who wrote ‘often with an indication of a fine median suture and a transverse suture in the posterior corners’. His figure 72 shows the coxopleural pore field with a short median posterior pore free area. This would appear to be an error.

Gardulla is within the known geographical range of
S. afer ,
which has been recorded from southern Sudan , Ethiopia , Somalia , Uganda , Zaire , Kenya , Zambia , Tanzania , Angola and north-eastern South Africa .

Scolopendra gardullana
is thus a junior synonym of
S. afer
.
